Graphical abstract Experimental testing and evaluation of catalysts in reactors is a central feature of fundamental catalysis science and reaction engineering. Measurements must be reproducible and interpretable to provide evidence for mechanistic studies or structure–function relationships, or to yield robust and intrinsically meaningful parameters to enable reactor scale-up and process development. Consequently, catalysis practitioners should seek to plan and perform catalyst testing in a manner that distinguishes between the intrinsic chemical kinetics governed by the catalyst and hydrodynamic, transport, and deactivation processes introduced by the form of the catalyst, the reactor vessel, and the nature of the contacting fluid. We highlight the importance of clear testing procedures for both the individual practitioner and the catalysis community and then discuss the sources and methods to address key sources of artifacts in catalyst testing. We organize sections in the form of questions practitioners should ask themselves when planning a catalyst testing campaign. This article references the original literature but also recasts the catalyst testing procedure in the form of a workflow diagram and illustrated depictions of the control experiments implemented within our laboratories to minimize the occurrence of artifacts. The content reflects our collective knowledge in the design, set up, and use of laboratory scale reactors for catalyst testing. Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Motivation Catalysis science and reaction engineering combine examinations of chemical bond breaking and formation events at catalytic sites with measurements (or predictions) for the rates at which these events occur. The catalyst and the reactive species undergo complementary changes during each catalytic cycle. The structure of the catalytic material may simultaneously evolve at a timescale different from that of catalytic turnover. The defining characteristic of a catalytic sequence, however, is an inherent circularity that restores the catalyst to its nascent state at the completion of a closed reaction sequence that transforms reactants to products [1,2]. Consequently, evaluation of these reaction events and their rates of occurrence endures as a quintessential component of catalysis science and reaction engineering. Both the science and the application of catalysis require accurate descriptions of rates as functions of the well-characterized and physically significant variables on which they depend (e.g., thermodynamic activities of chemical species, elemental composition and topological structure of the catalyst, surface characteristics of the material at reaction conditions, and the hydrothermal stability and sensitivity to chemical impurities). Catalyst testing and evaluation aims to generate this knowledge in order to accurately identify the individual significance of reaction events within the catalytic cycle; the transport of mass and energy between the catalyst and the surrounding fluid; and the evolution of the catalyst structure in response to the reactive environment [2–4]. This knowledge spans multiple length- and timescales, and once obtained, guides catalysis scientists and practitioners in multiple pursuits. Recent perspectives discussed recommendations for reporting the synthesis of solid catalysts [5] and best practices for investigations in heterogeneous catalysis that draw upon complementary areas of expertise [6]. Here, we adapt discussions from a recent workshop [7] aim to provide more specific and actionable guidance useful to practitioners (and newcomers to our field) for the design of catalyst tests and the evaluation of the measurements to achieve multiple categories of objectives (vide infra). Determination of Mechanisms and Intrinsic Kinetics. High-fidelity experimental testing results provide the basis to determine the mechanisms and intrinsic kinetics of catalytic reactions. Analysis of rate measurements provides evidence for the identity of crucial reactive intermediates and intervening elementary steps that dictate rates and selectivities for the formation of products. The literature of our field contains numerous examples in which precise kinetic measurements and their subsequent interpretation through comparisons to rate expressions derived from molecularly detailed sequences of elementary steps reveal the role of specific chemical processes (among plausible suggestions or outside prior expectations). Developments in in situ spectroscopies (i.e., methods that ascertain aspects of the electronic, crystallographic, coordinative, or vibrational structure of catalysts and associated complexes) and computational methods (e.g., ab initio electronic structure calculations, multiscale simulations, machine learning, and data science) delivered capabilities that surpass the expectations of researchers from the past two decades. Nevertheless, catalyst testing and the interpretation of kinetic measurements remain a foundational and necessary component of catalysis science, because experimental measurements reveal unexpected physical phenomena (not yet captured in computation) and predominantly report on chemical events and species occurrent at active sites at process conditions (whereas spectroscopic methods possess different forms of sensitivities and selection rules). Establishment of Structure-Function Relationships. Comparisons among rates, selectivities, and other experimental observables across a series of homologous catalysts differentiated by an intentional variance in a compositional or structural feature reveal how the performance of a family of catalysts depends on variables that may be controlled via synthesis, post-synthesis treatments, or formulation. These experimental structure–function relationships hold a central role in the design of catalysts for specific classes of chemical transformations. In addition, these relationships inform complementary mechanistic studies by divulging the means to preferentially stabilize crucial reactive intermediates and examine the impact on measured rates to test hypotheses. High-throughput experimental capabilities offer the means to vastly increase the number of catalysts that one can create, characterize, and test; however, these methods remain most effective when used to accelerate testing of specific hypotheses derived from mechanistic insight or fundamental understanding of materials chemistry. Chronicles of Catalyst Performance. Accurate and reproducible catalyst testing methods remain important, regardless of a practitioner’s interest in the mechanism of the reaction or how kinetics differ among materials with distinct composition or structure. Knowledge of the stability of a material following thermochemical treatments or use; the evolution of rates, selectivities, and yields for a reaction as a function of time on stream; and effective methods to regenerate the catalyst impact process design and economics directly. This remains true for catalytic materials with unknown or proprietary composition or structure. Quantitative measures of the stability and lifetime of a catalyst fall within the purview of catalyst testing and evaluation. Rates of catalytic deactivation and physically informed models for the mechanism of catalyst deactivation (e.g., loss of active sites, accumulation of organic residues, modification of catalytic centers) endure as key objectives of catalyst testing. Baseline Requirements for Catalyst Testing. Regardless of category of goals that motivate a catalyst testing campaign, reproducible and rigorous measurements and interpretations of reaction rates require that a minimal set of physical properties of the reaction media (e.g., initial and final concentrations, temperature), of the catalyst particle and catalyst bed (e.g., characteristic dimension, surface area, gradients in concentrations and temperature), and of the reactor vessel (e.g., flow rates, dimensions) are known and reported. The number and detail of these properties increase together with the specificity of the goals for an investigation. For example, mechanistic investigations require precise knowledge of concentration and temperature gradients across a relatively uniform population of active sites. Structure-function relationships benefit from accurate measures of the number of active sites and characterization of the electronic or topological properties of these sites for each among a series of materials. Studies that establish the performance of catalysts may require mass-averaged rates, selectivities, and yields obtained from experiments that exceed the duration of mechanistic studies by orders of magnitude (e.g., weeks versus hours). Standardization in catalyst testing and in reporting results of catalyst testing are needed to enhance rigor and reproducibility in catalysis research. 2 Procedural aspects of catalyst testing Testing of heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., supported nanoparticles, high surface oxides, solid acids) involves contacting these solid materials with a fluid within reactor vessels, which requires that reactor hydrodynamics and mixing be considered when evaluating catalyst performance. Diffusive transport of reactants and products also influences rates, selectivities, and catalyst lifetimes, particularly for porous materials. The effects of these transport processes (i.e., fluid flow, mass and heat transfer, and mixing) depend strongly on reactor and catalyst geometry and length scales, and therefore, catalyst performance does not scale directly among all forms of lab-scale reactors (units with characteristic dimensions commonly below 0.1 m). Moreover, performance in lab-scale reactors cannot directly predict performance within industrial-scale reactor vessels (characteristic dimensions often much greater than 1 m). These considerations demonstrate that the outcome of catalyst tests involve chemical and transport processes that bridge across many length- and timescales. Reactor performance for many length scales and reactor configurations can be predicted from catalytic testing under ideal conditions that yield intrinsic rates and selectivities of catalytic events [1,2]. As a result, intrinsic measurements of catalytic kinetics possess the greatest value and broadest applicability for the science and application of catalysis. Such measurements require the selection and operation of lab-scale reactors in a manner appropriate to either (1) eliminate or suppress the effects of transport and catalyst evolution during measurements, or (2) characterize and account for the influence of mass and energy transfer and hydrodynamics during testing and data analysis. In both cases, investigators should report sufficient details concerning catalyst testing apparatus, reactor vessel, and tests or validation performed to justify the conclusions that address case (1) or case (2). With a goal to establish standards for reports of catalyst testing, a series of key questions emerge. First, what particulars of catalyst testing should be reported or demonstrated to ensure that catalyst performance characteristics and measurements are reproducible (e.g., fluid flow configurations; pressure - pressure drop and temperature - temperature gradients; structure of catalyst bed; method for forming catalyst pellets and placement in the reactor; measurements at fractional conversion of limiting reagents; effects of residence time on rates and selectivity, etc.)? Second, are certain metrics or benchmark materials required to be incorporated in catalyst testing studies (e.g., specific methods for normalization of rates; selectivity comparisons at constant conversion; turnover numbers for a particular duration; inclusion of measurements obtained for widely available benchmark materials, etc.)? The sections that follow parse reaction and transport phenomena at the catalyst bed and catalyst pellet length scales, and thereafter, present questions a researcher should ask and address when reporting catalytic data acquired in a laboratory. 3 Technical questions to address in the acquisition of laboratory scale catalytic data 3.1 What reactor scale phenomena are relevant for catalyst testing? Is it an ideal reactor? Reliable catalyst evaluation and testing requires the selection of a reactor with appropriate hydrodynamics and confirmation that the reactor adheres to the behavior described by the reactor design equations and the underlying assumptions pertaining to mixing (i.e., mass, momentum, and energy transport), as highlighted in prior literature [1,2]. These foundational concepts merit repeating because deviation from these guidelines significantly impedes the ability to reproduce measurements of catalytic performance of identical materials among, and even within, research laboratories. Catalyst testing in reactor vessels frequently involves physical phenomena that differ from the idealized descriptions of these systems (e.g., spatial gradients in concentrations and temperature, transient or non-steady state operation, back-mixing, etc.). We first outline the limiting conditions for reactor operation in Table 1 to help clarify the reasoning used to establish recommendations for data acquisition and reporting and to illustrate how transport and catalyst evolution impact observed performance [3]. Catalyst evaluation and testing employs many reactor configurations and modes of operation. Common examples include packed bed reactors, continuous flow stirred tank reactors, external recycle reactors (that mimic batch stirred tank reactors if no outlet is provided), and conventional batch stirred tank reactors. Textbooks describe the ideal design equations for configuration (the text by Davis and Davis is freely available) [2], however, researchers should question their assumptions when designing their catalyst testing method. Does the laboratory scale reactor perform equivalent to the ideal reactor described in the design equation? Catalyst tests are most readily interpreted when researchers select and operate their lab-scale reactors to achieve essentially isobaric, isochoric, and isothermal operation in hydrodynamically ideal reactors (e.g., plug flow reactor, continuous stirred tank reactor, or batch stirred tank reactor). What tests affirm that the laboratory reactor operated under idealized conditions? In order to answer this question, researchers should employ two common approaches: functional experimental tests such as those outlined by Madon and Boudart [8], and the use of established empirical relationships such as the Koros-Nowak criterion [9] and the Mears criterion [10]. The outcomes from experimental tests are most likely to be reproduced accurately in other reactors when these methods are implemented (and vice versa). The intent of these criteria is summarized by a simple principle: Minimize gradients of concentrations, pressure, temperature, and rates with respect to position and time. We highlight a few key questions and methods relevant for selection and operation of ideal laboratory reactors. 3.1.1 What can be done to ensure isothermal and isobaric operation? Temperature and concentration (i.e., activity or chemical potential) are driving forces for catalytic reactions. These variables affect rates of reactions but also the thermodynamic end point for a reaction (i.e., equilibrium). Thus, it is imperative that isothermal and isobaric operation be achieved in lab-scale reactors. Researchers should report methods and instrumentation used to acquire temperature and pressure conditions relevant for catalyst testing (e.g., make, model, and accuracy of apparatus) and the location of these devices. For example, the temperature of a catalyst bed may differ from the temperature at the outer wall of a reactor or the inner surface of a furnace. Thus, thermocouples located within a catalyst bed (i.e., in direct contact with the catalyst pellets, Scheme 1) frequently show temperatures that differ by significant values, and the temperature of the catalyst bed from an internal thermocouple takes precedence among these measurements for obtaining reproducible measurements. The inclusion of a thermocouple within a concentric thermowell can, however, introduce deviations from ideal flow patterns which impact interpretation of rate measurements at non-differential conversions. Additionally, a measurement of temperature or pressure at a single location does not ensure isothermal or isobaric operation. The following protocols facilitate catalyst testing under isothermal and isobaric conditions. In many cases, isothermal operation can be achieved by diluting catalyst pellets with inert pellets of comparable size within beds and by creating pellets from mixtures of catalyst powder and a powder derived from a chemically inert and thermally conductive material (e.g., co-pelletizing with silicon carbide), illustrated in Scheme 1. Both strategies seek to reduce the quantity of heat generated or consumed per unit volume (or mass) of the packed bed while maintaining or increasing the effective thermal conductivity of the catalyst bed. Experimental protocols for catalyst tests that demonstrate the absence of thermal gradients are outlined and demonstrated in many prior reports. We simply highlight that dilution of catalysts within pellets and dilution within beds are meant to eliminate temperature gradients that may exist at different length scales, and in some cases, these approaches must be combined to ensure isothermal operation. Excessive dilution can, however, result in reactor bypass in certain limiting cases which introduce additional difficulties [11,12]. Experimental studies most directly demonstrate the absence of temperature gradients for a designated set of materials, especially for porous or formulated catalysts whose thermal properties are not well-characterized. These experimental tests can be combined with criteria developed by Mears [10,13], Anderson [14], and Balakotaiah et al. [15] to predict the absence of temperature gradients provided that the necessary physical properties are known. Essentially, a system with negligible temperature gradients must show identical mass-averaged reaction rates (e.g., (mol product) (mass reactive powder s)-1) when the ratio of reactive and inert powders is varied within the catalyst pellets and within the packed bed. Along the same lines, isobaric operation may be achieved by increasing catalyst pellet diameters, increasing reactor diameter, decreasing packing fraction, decreasing catalyst bed length or volumetric flow rates as described by the Ergun equation [2] among others. The sensible pressure drop must be measured (e.g., through use of pressure transducers located immediately upstream and downstream of the packed bed, Scheme 1) and reported to demonstrate the absence or presence of pressure drop and suitable corrections should be included in reporting catalytic data [16]. 3.1.2 Do concentration gradients impede ideal reactor operation, and when does a reactor operate at differential conditions? Rates of reactions and rates of catalyst deactivation most commonly depend on the concentrations (i.e., thermodynamic activity) of species introduced or formed during the reactions including the reactants, intermediates, and product molecules. Spatial gradients in the concentrations of these species, therefore, give rise to differences in rates throughout reactors: the normalized rate of reaction at the inlet may differ substantially from the normalized rate of reaction at the outlet or other locations [2]. Consequently, significant concentration gradients in packed bed reactors impede the operation of laboratory reactors under ideal conditions and introduce substantial uncertainties to reported rates and catalyst performance. One common heuristic used to avoid concentration gradients across catalyst beds is that low conversions of the limiting reactant (<10 %) leads to a negligible reactant concentration gradient between the inlet and outlet, and therefore, the reactor can be considered to operate at differential conversion with negligible effects from gradients in concentration. Notably, the design equations for multiple reactor configurations (e.g., plug flow reactors and continuous stirred tank reactors) become equivalent in the limit of differential conversion, which allows for simple calculations of rates from measured fractional conversions of the reactants. In practice, low conversions are achieved by operating at sufficiently high ratios of the feed flow rate to the mass of the catalyst bed (i.e., high space velocities and low residence times [2]). The implicit assumption is that reaction rates exhibit a linear or sublinear dependence on the concentration of the limiting reagent and do not change in response to variations in the concentrations of other species. This heuristic, however, is not entirely correct and can lead to significant errors. Reaction rates frequently depend on concentrations of intermediates and product species formed during catalysis. Significantly, the concentrations of these species at the inlet of a flow reactor or at the onset of a reaction in a closed vessel are equal to zero, and therefore, any non-zero concentration represents a relatively large rise in concentration. As an example, the products of a reaction may bind strongly to the catalytic active site and inhibit adsorption and conversion of reactants. As a consequence, rates may decrease with a near exponential dependence on distance from the inlet in a plug flow reactor or as a function of residence time (or reactant conversion) in a continuous or batch stirred tank reactor, as exemplified in kinetic studies of alkene epoxidation on microporous titanosilicates (epoxide inhibits)[17,18], hydrogenolysis of furans upon transition metal and metal phosphide nanoparticles (carbon monoxide inhibits) [19], and oxidation of nitrous oxide on Cu-exchanged aluminosilicates (nitrogen dioxide inhibits) [18,20]. Product formation rates measured as functions of residence time report on the significance of concentration gradients across the catalyst bed, but these experiments serve also to distinguish between products formed by primary and secondary reactions and to reveal the approach to equilibrium among subsets of reactions [21]. Fig. 1 shows findings from such experiments that demonstrate the absence of consequential concentration gradients and the formation of both H2O2 and water (H2O) by primary reaction pathways [22]. Strictly speaking, differential operation of laboratory scale reactors occurs only when the concentrations of all species that impact rates remain nearly constant across the span of spatial positions and operating times of the reactors (i.e., spatial and time gradients in concentrations are negligible). These gradients are difficult to characterize directly, but the presence and significance of concentration gradients in a flow reactor can be assessed directly by measuring product formation rates (and reactant consumption rates) at multiple volumetric flow rates of the entering fluid using a single charge of catalyst and operating at low to modest reactant conversions (2–20 %). Gradients may be considered insignificant when apparent rates do not vary when fluid flow rates increase and decrease by at least a factor of two, which leads to more than a four-fold change in mean residence time of the fluid within the reactor. When concentration gradients are negligible, reactant conversions increase linearly with the residence time and mass- or site-normalized rates remain constant (Fig. 1b) [8–10,13]. Notably, this methodology also probes external mass transfer limitations arising between the fluid and catalyst particles by convection (i.e., transport across boundary layers that surround the catalyst particles, vide infra). In cases where the characteristics of the reaction cause products to inhibit the rate of the reaction, spatial gradients in reaction rates may be minimized by intentionally co-feeding small concentrations of the product or a molecule with similar chemical function (e.g., substituting one aromatic hydrocarbon for another) with the reactants [19,20]. For example, molecularly meaningful measurements of NO oxidation rates were achieved when co-feeding NO2 while examining the effects of the pressures of reactants (NO, O2) and residence time on rates (Fig. 2 ) [20]. To conclude, rates measured without assessments of concentration gradients or with immeasurable concentration gradients (e.g., at complete conversion of reactants) have resulted in many reports in the broader literature documenting irreproducible or uninterpretable results. The methods described above should be followed in the process of catalyst testing and evaluation for any of the goals portrayed in Scheme 1. 3.1.3 Is the reactor hydrodynamically ideal? Reactor design equations must be used to calculate reaction rates based upon measured differences between the initial and final composition of the fluid, and these design equations derive from limiting assumptions for the hydrodynamics and mixing that occurs within the reactor vessel (Table 1) [2]. Deviations from the assumptions for each model reduce the accuracy and reproducibility of reported rates and catalyst performance. Although laboratory scale reactors frequently do achieve the criteria for ideal plug flow in packed bed flow reactors, criteria have been reported to affirm that no significant deviation from plug flow configurations results [23]. Traditional heuristics call for internal diameters of tubular reactors to be 10–20 times greater than the average diameter of particle pellets to ensure ideal flow of fluid through the catalyst bed and not through voids formed by irregularities in packing pellets at the interior wall of the reactor (Scheme 1). These criteria are equally important for gas–solid and gas–liquid-solid reactors and become more challenging to satisfy for systems that exhibit non-turbulent flow (i.e., low Reynolds numbers) and when using short catalytic beds [24]. The addition of an inert packing material (e.g., acid-washed quartz wool, glass chips, etc.) before and after the catalyst pellets can partially mitigate these effects by inducing plug flow hydrodynamics prior to contact with the reactive material. Packed bed reactors with external recycle streams can operate as batch reactors or as continuous stirred tank reactors in limiting cases. In both situations, the single pass conversion through the packed bed should be kept low (<1% conversion) to ensure that the contents of the reactor can be considered well-mixed. In those cases, when practitioners aim to describe the system with design equations for a CSTR, high ratios (>25) of the external recycle flow rate to the flow rate that leaves the system are required to ensure residence time distributions mimic those of an idealized CSTR. Correlations to determine particle fluid mass and heat transfer [25] as well as illustrative case studies highlighting the role of bed scale mixing and gas solubility have been reported [26]. Once established, the hydrodynamics of a reactor or catalyst-loaded reactor (i.e., material within vessel) may be characterized to determine how closely the system aligns with the assumptions underlying the design equation [2]. The most direct manner by which to interrogate the hydrodynamics of continuous flow systems involves measurements of residence time distributions, which are accomplished by introducing a chemically inert tracer and measuring the elution of that tracer at the reactor outlet [27,28]. These methods may be used to examine systems with either gas- or liquid-phase fluid flow. The preferred method involves a step change (or narrow pulse) of the tracer at the reactor inlet followed by analysis of the concentration of the tracer in the effluent stream using a detector with temporal resolution much greater than the average residence time of the fluid in the reactor (e.g., use of mass spectrometer or thermal conductivity detector for gaseous streams, ion conductivity detector for liquids). Measurements of residence time distributions reactors rarely match those for ideal reactors, and knowledge of the extent to which a system deviates from the ideal behavior can assist practitioners in the interpretation and prediction of catalyst testing results. 3.1.4 When can reactor operation be considered to have achieved steady state conditions? Structure-function relationships and evaluation of catalyst performance, two key objectives of catalyst testing (Scheme 2), often rely on the ability of researchers to compare data at steady state conditions. There are however, no well-defined or well-established criteria that define when reactor operation can be considered as steady state. Thus, a very important aspect of catalyst testing is for researchers to document and report the dependence of rates as a function of time-on-stream. The best practice for researchers is to report rates measured as a function of time in flow reactors to directly show the approach and achievement of steady state or to document clearly how corrections for catalyst deactivation are incorporated in calculations of catalyst performance. When transient operation is observed prior to attaining steady state operation, researchers should report the occurrence of such transients in published results and present representative measurements within supporting information. Transient changes in rates appear during many forms of hydrocarbon or oxygenate reforming reactions due to the accumulation of organic residues that reduce the number of accessible active site or rates of intrapellet diffusion on solid acid or bifunctional catalysts with examples that include methanol conversion to hydrocarbons or olefins [29,30], reduction of esters to ethers [31,32], and aldol condensation reactions [33–35] where catalysts show rates that decrease significantly within the first few hours of time on stream. In contrast, other catalytic chemistries may exhibit rates or selectivities that increase over periods of many hours or even days particularly when trace quantities of elements are introduced to promote a catalyst such as during epoxidation of ethylene on silver particles with chlorine and alkali and transition metal promoters [36–38] and formation of hydrogen peroxide on palladium nanoparticles in aqueous solutions containing chloride [39,40], bromide [41], or organic [42] promoters (see Fig. 3 ). Similarly, batch reactor data should include data taken as a function of time and the method for analyzing the data be described explicitly (e.g., differential, integral, or initial rate analysis). As examples, figures portraying the concentrations of reactants and products as functions of time (over ranges that include low reactant conversions, < 10 %) and explicit descriptions of the equations used to calculate rates from the time dependent behavior [18,43,44] carry greater importance than single time point measurements of reactant conversions or product yields. These measurements are necessary to show how reported rates depend on concentrations of species and to demonstrate rates do not conflate reaction progress and catalyst deactivation. For both flow and batch reactors, investigators should give evidence that demonstrates the material introduced to the reactor meets the definition of a catalyst: the material facilitates the chemical reaction many times over, or in other words, the material can achieve more than a single turnover or reaction event per active site. Practitioners can meet this recommendation, together with the criteria described above, by integrating rates as functions of time on stream to determine the cumulative number of reaction events per amount catalyst and ensure that allow practitioners to report normalized rates as functions of time on stream. Depending on the basis used to normalize rates (see 4.1.), practitioners should report data as catalytic rates only when turnover numbers ((mol product)(mol site)-1) or productivities ((mol product)(mol catalytic material)-1) achieve, and preferably, far surpass unity. Flow reactors assist in meeting these criteria (steady state, more than one turnover per site) by allowing researchers to extend the duration of a catalyst test. Use of batch reactors requires additional planning, because the quantity of reactant loaded must surpass the catalyst amount to allow for sufficiently high turnover numbers or productivity before the reactants are depleted. 3.1.5 What other control experiments and procedures useful for the operation of ideal laboratory reactors? Several noteworthy experimental practices provide greater evidence that the measured rates reflect contributions of the catalytic material introduced to the reactor. Randomizing the sequence of process parameters in catalyst testing allows for the deconvolution of catalyst deactivation from intrinsic kinetics and the use of reference or benchmark conditions repeated in independent experiments provides opportunities to assess deactivation rates. Measurements of rates with empty (or blank) reactors or reactors filled with inert solids demonstrate the presence or absence of surface reactions on the reactor walls, thermocouples, inert packing materials, or fluid transfer lines (Scheme 1) as well as homogeneous reactions within the fluid. Reactions catalyzed by metal nanoparticles (e.g., alkene hydrogenation, alkane dehydrogenation) may also occur on walls of metal reactor vessels, upon thermocouples, or purportedly inert diluents placed within the reactor therefore, practitioners should directly measure reactant conversion and product formation rates in the absence of the catalyst at comparable residence times and volumetric flowrates. When parasitic reactions occur on these surfaces, the materials of construction should be changed, or passivating treatments should be employed to suppress these reactions. Mass balances and the closure of mass balances should be reported. Preferably, the methods to calibrate analytical instruments and the accuracy of the analytical methods should be described. Schemes that communicate the reactor flow configuration together with the form and location of devices used to measure temperature, pressure, and flow rates, and the methods to control these parameters should be described. Flow rates of fluids (volumetric, molar, and superficial) must be known and controlled (e.g., mass flow controllers, pumps) to accurately establish flow patterns and regimes within reactors and to accurately control the composition of mixtures formed by combining multiple fluids within the apparatus. Methods used to calibrate these devices should be reported (e.g., use of bubble flowmeter to calibrate mass flow controllers, determination of sensitivity factors for analytical devices with calibrated gases mixtures, etc.). Protocols describing materials of construction for the reactor, source and chemical purity of all chemical reagents, chemical traps and adsorbents used to purify reagents, etc., can readily be included in supporting information that accompanies most published manuscripts. Several pages of text may be necessary to report these attributes of the reactor system. While creating a document with this level of detail may require significant time, the description of a specific catalyst testing system may be reproduced from prior reports (i.e., rather than citing an earlier publication) and edited to account for changes made to the apparatus. 3.1.6 Experimental characterization of reactor scale transport phenomena and potential artifacts Appropriately normalized reaction rates ( R ¯ ) should not depend on the quantity of catalyst present in a reactor, the hydrodynamics and rate of agitation (i.e., turbulence) in the reactor, or the ratio of the reactor volume to the volumetric flow rate (i.e., residence time) of the reactor, unless transport limitations during catalysis lead to consequential gradients in the concentration of reactive species or the temperature that span between the individual pellets of catalyst. Appropriate bases for the normalization of reaction rates include methods that scale linearly with the number of active site or proxies that report on the number of active sites (e.g., mass of reactive powder, surface of reactive powder, uptakes of chemical site titrants such as carbon monoxide or pyridine) as described later (Section 4.1). The presence of significant gradients across the reactor correspond to first Damkohler numbers ( D a I ; a dimensionless group that divides the intrinsic rate of the chemical process at the sensible conditions of the bulk fluid by the rate of convective transport across boundary layers and throughout the bed [45]) similar to or larger than unity. Under these limiting conditions ( D a I ≥ 1 ), individual catalyst pellets operate while in contact with fluid with distinct compositions and in this scenario temperature gradients may span across the reactor. These gradients preclude accurate measurements of the intrinsic catalytic rate or the development of structure–function relationships, and therefore, these spatial variations in composition and temperature must be minimized or eliminated. Investigations that seek to benchmark the performance of catalysts may involve reactions that operate with sensible gradients in concentrations and temperature, however, reproducibility requires that practitioners characterize and report these gradients. Fig. 4 portrays a sequence of phenomenological tests that establish the presence or absence of interparticle, interphase, and reactor-scale transport limitations. These tests involve manipulating the quantity or arrangement of catalyst pellets within the reactor or the agitation or fluid flow rates. First, a practitioner loads the reactor with different masses (or numbers) of reactive catalyst particles ( m c a t ) of fixed dimensions and compares values of R ¯ among these individual tests. This test reports on the significance of spatial gradients (in concentrations or temperature) and on interphase transport in systems that involve both gaseous and liquid fluid streams. In stirred tank reactors, a second test involves increasing the agitation of the fluid such as through use of higher stirring rates ( ω ), increasing the number of impellers, adding baffles upon the reactor walls or other approaches. These changes aim to increase the turbulence of the fluid (i.e., greater Reynolds number, R e ) and the interfacial area between the gas and liquid-phases when both are pertinent. In continuous flow reactors, a third test utilizes variations in the volumetric flow rate of the fluid stream ( ν ), which leads to differences in R e (and associated changes in turbulence and convective transport rates) and proportional differences in the residence time ( τ ). Again, comparisons between measured R ¯ values must remain constant to exclude the possibility of interparticle, interphase, and reactor-scale transport limitations. Frequently, the first and either the second or third test, depending on the type of reactor configuration used, can be combined to give strong evidence of the absence of transport limitations. 3.2 What pellet scale phenomena are relevant for catalyst testing? What distinguishes these from reactor scale phenomena for catalytic testing? Simply stated, gradients in concentration or temperature can exist at the catalyst bed or reactor scale as we discuss above (Section 3.1) but can also arise at the scale of a catalyst pellet either due to interphase gradients (e.g., transport of heat and mass across boundary layers between fluids and solids or between gas and liquid interfaces) or due to intraparticle gradients (e.g., diffusion of heat and mass within porous solids). These gradients can substantially impact rates but are not directly sensible by measurement devices or analytical methods available in most laboratories. The presence or absence of these gradients should either be estimated using reported non-dimensional parameters or experimentally probed by varying diameters of pellets, the number of reactive sites per pellet, the volumetric flow rates of fluid through a fixed bed, the agitation rate of a batch stirred tank reactor, etc. Many prior reports document these methods and discuss the calculation of appropriate non-dimensional parameters (e.g., the effectiveness factor, η , Fig. 5 ) based on the observed or estimated reaction rate over a catalyst particle of known physical properties and some estimate of the kinetics of the underlying reaction [46]. Noteworthy among these are the Weisz-Prater criterion [15], Koros-Nowak criterion [16], the Mears criterion [5], and the Madon-Boudart criterion [17]. Detailed discussion and instruction on the application of these criteria can be found in many textbooks and publications [1,2,18]. A brief summary of the core tenets is presented. 3.2.1 Experimental characterization of pellet scale transport phenomena and potential artifacts Appropriately normalized reaction rates ( R ¯ ) will not change with characteristic dimensions, micron-scale structure, or manner of combining reactive powder catalysts with inert material, unless transport limitations during catalysis lead to consequential gradients in the concentration of reactive species or the temperature of the material. Methods for the calculation of normalized rates remain consistent with those described for tests that probe reactor scale transport phenomena. The presence of significant gradients in catalyst pellets lead to values of the Thiele modulus ( φ ) or the second Damkohler number ( D a I I ) (i.e., dimensionless groupings of terms that divide the intrinsic rate of the chemical process at the sensible conditions of the bulk fluid by the rate of diffusive mass transport within the pellet [2,45]) similar to or larger than unity. Under these limiting conditions ( φ ≥ 1 ), the active sites distributed within each catalyst pellet sense different local concentrations and temperatures and provide reaction rates dependent upon their spatial location in the catalyst pellet (i.e., η ≠ 1). Consequently, the observed rate represents an average obtained from a broad distribution of rates (and potentially selectivities) per active site. The presence of these variations shows that the manner in which the catalyst pellet is created depends on both the synthesis of the primary catalyst powder and the way in which this is combined with other materials (e.g., inert diluents, binders) to create formulated pellets. High fidelity measurements of the intrinsic rate of reaction of the catalyst require that such intraparticle gradients and the associated artifacts are eliminated. Fig. 6 depicts a well-documented series of observational tests that can effectively establish the presence or absence of intraparticle and intrapellet transport limitations. Unlike calculations meant to anticipate the likelihood of transport limitations based on physical properties of materials and chemicals (e.g., effective diffusion coefficients, intrinsic rate constants, vide infra), these tests involve comparisons of normalized rates among catalyst pellets that vary either in the fraction of reactive powder (in contrast to inert powder) in the aggregated pellet; the number of active sites formed per particle of reactive powder; or the mean diameter of the catalyst pellet created with a fixed composition of reactive and inert powders. Respectively, these tests involve three simple material preparation steps. First, a practitioner co-pelletizes the reactive powder (i.e., the catalyst of interest) and an inert powder together into a series of pellets with a fixed size. Normalized rates are compared across the series of materials formed by varying the fraction of reactive powder in the pellets ( χ r ). Second, the practitioner varies the synthesis procedure to achieve different numbers of active sites ( L ) on the reactive powder, and the resulting series of materials are formed into pellets with constant diameters ( d p ) and with fixed fractions of reactive and inert powders. Third, the practitioner maintains value of both χ r and L and forms a series of pellets that differ in values of d p . Again, comparisons among the values of R ¯ obtained from the series of pellets formed must remain constant to exclude the possibility of intraparticle or intrapellet mass or energy transport limitations. In practice, the second test most directly provides a clear conclusion but may require synthesis of a greater number of catalytic materials. Fig. 7 shows measurements from a series of experiments performed in a fixed bed reactor that probe both reactor and pellet scale transport phenomena during reactions among hydrogen and oxygen in an aqueous methanol solvent that flow through a packed bed of catalyst pellets comprised of palladium nanoparticles supported on silica [40]. Results are presented as measured hydrogen conversions as functions of surface residence time ( τ ): a quantity that compares the number of surface sites to the molar flow rate of the limiting reagent (i.e., (mol Pdsurface s) (mol H2)-1). These data show that conversion increases linearly with τ for all materials (i.e., normalized rates are equal at different flow rates, third test from Fig. 4), which demonstrates neither interpellet nor interphase transport affect measured rates. Additionally, conversions measured at a given value of τ increase with decreasing loading of palladium nanoparticles on silica pellets of fixed porosity, surface area, and mean diameters (i.e., second test from Fig. 6 ). This comparison demonstrates that intrapellet transport limitations were consequential when the mass loading of palladium nanoparticles on silica was equal to or greater than 0.1 % wt. palladium and became undetectable when these loadings decreased to values of 0.05 % wt. palladium and lower. 3.3 Non-experimental estimates for the probability of transport limitations. Quantitative comparisons between rates of chemical reactions to rates of mass, momentum, or energy transport are captured within dimensionless numbers described in reaction engineering textbooks. The values of these quantities provide convenient methods to estimate the influence of transport processes on observed rates or selectivities of chemical reactions obtained from catalyst tests. A recent online web-based tool in the public domain, GradientCheck ( www.GradientCheck.com ), utilizes calculations for these dimensionless groups to estimate the likelihood that a reactor contains consequential gradients of temperature, pressure, or concentrations throughout the catalyst bed or within individual pellets [23]. This tool, and others that rely upon the use of dimensionless quantities (e.g., Da I , Da II , φ ) requires researchers to input various physical parameters for their system but requires that these parameters are known, which is not always possible. Consequently, direct experimental tests for transport affects remain an important to ensure rigor and reproducibility in catalyst testing. We highlight other common questions and concerns relevant to catalyst testing below. 3.4 Can these control experiments be used effectively after completing catalyst testing? Unfortunately, these criteria can rarely be applied during ex post facto analysis of published results by other researchers. Comparisons of catalyst tests conducted between reactors and between laboratories are rarely done or reported because many parameters used to assess the role of interphase and intraparticle gradients depend upon material and process parameters (e.g., particle diameter and morphology, reactor wall temperature) that are not routinely reported. Preferably, these calculations should be reported for every case study and both methods and calculations be archived in simple tabular format either in the publication or in the supporting information that accompanies the manuscript. We strongly encourage researchers to conduct the control experiments described (vide supra, Figs. 4 and 6) before conducting further tests that strike at the heart of the scientific or engineering question of interest. By characterizing or eliminating (when appropriate) the effects of non-ideal hydrodynamics, transport processes, or transient operation of catalysts, practitioners will improve the rigor and reproducibility of their research efforts. 3.5 In cases where gradients are intrinsic to reactions what can be done? What if ideal flow patterns, steady state conditions, or isobaric and isothermal conditions do not exist in the reactor? We anticipate scenarios where heat and mass transfer gradients are difficult to eliminate or unavoidable due to intrinsic characteristics of the network of reactions (e.g., cascade reactions, bifunctional systems with gaseous intermediates), when strongly exothermic or endothermic reactions are involved, when products of side reactions inhibit or poison sites, or when using non-standard reactors (e.g., membrane reactors). No standardized protocols account for all scenarios; however, we surmise a handful of control experiments and reporting practices on behalf of researchers would enable robust interpretation of catalytic data acquired under these conditions (vide supra). Parametric studies that report on these gradients and that estimate the magnitude of these gradients carry significant value and improve the robustness of the catalytic data. A best practice would be to report limiting conditions (e.g., higher temperatures, lower volumetric flow rates, etc.) for such parametric studies and to report in detail the conditions, methods, and criteria examined to assess the role of heat and mass transfer gradients at the pellet scale. 4 How should results of catalyst testing be reported? Central to the objectives of catalyst testing are systematic comparisons of rate and selectivity among different formulations. Common impediments to comparisons and reproducibility of catalyst testing data among laboratories is the use of reporting metrics that render direct comparisons either infeasible or inaccurate. Examples include measurements taken at or near complete conversion of the limiting reagent, measurements acquired when the reactions of interest operate near equilibrium, and measurements of the sensible temperature required to achieve a specific conversion. The simplest answer to this question is researchers should report normalized rates of reaction and not conversion or temperature required to attain a specific conversion. We highlight other common questions and concerns relevant to reporting results of catalyst testing below. 4.1 What should rates be normalized to and what units should the rate have? A hierarchy of preferences exists for calculations of normalized reaction rates ( R ¯ ). The rates of these chemical events ((moles of events) (s)-1) are typically determined by the rate of formation or depletion of a specific molecule (e.g., (moles of product) (s)-1), which succeeds most frequently for reaction systems that involve few individual steps and involve reactants and products unique to each step. Most preferably, these rates are normalized by an estimate for the number of active centers in the catalyst bed. These values may be described as turnover rates and possess units consistent with (moles of products) (moles of active sites · s)-1. In these cases, the number of active sites in the catalyst bed will be assessed by in situ reactive titration techniques or spectroscopic methods, and the experimental procedures, assumptions, and calculations should be reported. If such information is unavailable, then rates should be normalized by the number of exposed atoms of the catalytically active element as assessed by ex situ methods (e.g., chemisorption of carbon monoxide, hydrogen, oxygen), which should be reported in units consistent with (moles of product) (moles of exposed element ·s)-1. Less preferably, the rate can be normalized by total quantity of the active element present within the sample and should be indicated with units similar to (moles of product) (moles of element ·s)-1. Least preferably, rates would be normalized by total mass of catalyst ((mole product) (gram catalyst·s)-1). The order of preference corresponds to the increasingly unique and informative nature of these normalized rates with turnover rates signifying a specific characteristic of the intensive catalytic properties of the material and mass-averaged rates representing a value which does not readily allow comparison among catalysts formulated with different compositions or by different methods. The full units used for these calculations should be reported in figures and tables in the manuscript. We anticipate scenarios where an abundance of reaction pathways and species and/or network connectivity prevents accurate assessment of rates of individual steps. In such cases, specific rates of reactant consumption and rates of product formation be reported, however, practitioners must consider that multiple reactions contribute to these measurements. Along similar lines, steady state operation may not be obtained in catalytic chemistries where catalyst deactivation or spatiotemporal variation in rates occur frequently. Here, the best practice is to report turnover numbers (i.e., the integral of the normalized rate, R ¯ , from initiation of catalysis to complete deactivation) with preferences for units that parallel those described for rates. 4.2 What limits the utility of conversion-selectivity based metrics in catalyst testing? The fractional conversion of a specific reactant in a catalytic process is not an intrinsic measure of reactivity but instead is a process dependent variable that reflects multiple catalyst independent and catalyst dependent parameters including reactor hydrodynamics (e.g., plug flow or back-mixing) and process parameters (e.g., mass of catalyst bed and fluid flow rate) in addition to intensive catalyst properties (e.g., mass normalized rate at a specific combination of temperature and concentrations, mass fraction of catalytically active component in formulated materials). Consequently, reactant conversions can be manipulated (inadvertently or intentionally) to achieve any value ranging from nearly zero conversion to complete (or equilibrium) conversion by simply varying space velocity in flow reactors (the ratio of fluid flow rate to catalyst quantity; or time in batch reactors), temperature, heat and mass transport, or hydrodynamics. While the choice of a common set of reaction conditions within a study does allow comparison among the samples at the selected conditions, the use of conversion as a metric of catalyst performance renders difficult comparison to reports from the literature. Similarly, the temperature required to attain a specific chemical conversion (e.g., 50 % of the limiting reagent) can be biased by changing fluid flow rates and catalyst bed loading, while fixing all other experimental parameters. Data reported at complete or equilibrium conversion has little to no scientific or technical value, except as part of a sequence of data that show the approach to these high conversions from much lower values. The ability to achieve complete conversion does not represent a unique property of the catalyst or provide a quantitatively significant measurement, because these values may be controlled by fluid flow rates (or reaction time in a batch reactor), temperature, etc. [47]. Furthermore, the space time, reaction time, or temperature required to first achieve complete (equilibrium) conversion frequently is less than the time or temperature reported. 4.3 What procedures and calculations should be reported for catalyst testing? Researchers should report all material and process parameters at which catalyst testing was undertaken (e.g., final temperatures of thermal treatment but rates at which temperatures were ramped or durations for which they were held constant, fluid flow rates, catalyst bed loading, pre-mixing or pre-heating of fluids, etc.). Researchers should also define explicitly the metrics of performance for catalyst testing (e.g., selectivity, normalized rate, conversion, etc.). A detailed description of procedures used in assessing results and/or sample calculations for a data set should be included in the manuscript or supporting information. These reporting practices would eliminate common pitfalls such as considering that a low single pass conversion of the reactant (e.g., below 10 % chemical conversion) demonstrates true differential conversion. As stated earlier, the regime of differential conversion is defined by a range of conversion throughout which the change in concentration of all species that affect rates (i.e., reactants, intermediates, and products) remains negligible. The definition of what may be considered negligible changes in rates and selectivities may differ with the use of the data, and therefore, researchers must determine what this means for their purposes and report that criterion. In cases where products inhibit the rate, there is virtually no conversion low enough to give differential behavior without cofeeding product or chemical surrogates for the reaction products. Here, particular care is needed to properly report results of catalyst testing. The effects of these processes on measured rates should be directly assessed by measuring rates of formation of products and consumption of reactants as functions of fluid flow rate through the catalyst bed to functionally ascertain the range of fractional reactant conversion that can be demonstrated to be truly differential conversion at the conditions employed. For reactions that are known to be limited by chemical equilibria, practitioners should discuss how thermodynamic constraints may or may not influence the reported rates and conversions. When appropriate, the approach-to-equilibrium values, which equal the reaction quotient divided by the equilibrium constant, should be provided. These values can then be used to calculate forward rates of reactions from the measured net rates of reaction [48]. Fig. 8 displays representative product selectivities for cycloalkane hydrogenolysis reactions along with the approach to equilibrium for the dehydrogenation of the cycloalkane reactants (η) over supported iridium nanoparticles. These plots together with calculated turnover rates ((mol reactant consumed) (mol Irsurface s)-1) demonstrated that reactions operated near differential conversion, reaction intermediates did not inhibit rates, (de)hydrogenation of the reactant was equilibrated, and that certain subsets of products (e.g., multiple hydrogenolysis species comprised of light alkanes) are formed in secondary reactions [49]. For tests performed in continuous flow reactors, the time sequence of conditions used during catalyst testing should be described, and researchers should return to a common set of conditions (i.e., fluid flow rate, inlet fluid composition, reactor temperature). Testing often involves a series of different steps including variation in flow rates, inlet composition, and reactor temperature. Although a catalyst may achieve an apparent steady state at each set of condition, those results may depend on the order of conditions selected due to changes in the structure of the catalyst that are irreversible on the timescale of the catalyst testing procedure. Examples of these types of changes include nanoparticle sintering or agglomeration, deactivation due to the accumulation or loss of material (e.g., organic residues or coke, contamination by metal or sulfur in the feed, dissolution or sublimation of the catalyst). The presence of such processes can be identified by confirming that reaction rates and selectivities remain constant at a common set of conditions and are not affected by the duration or sequence of the stages used to test the catalyst. The protocol used for confirming the absence of changes should be reported. When catalysts do evolve irreversibly, the nature of these changes must be reported, and the sequence of steps used during testing must be described in detail. Otherwise, the outcome of these tests cannot be reliably reproduced by other researchers even if all other details of the catalytic materials and apparatus are identical. Selected catalyst testing measurements should be replicated a minimum of three times to demonstrate the reproducibility of the complete workflow and to allow for the calculation of uncertainties that account for all steps in the process of loading, pretreating, and testing a catalyst within a reactor. Sources of uncertainty detected by this approach include error in the mass of material loaded into the reactor, non-idealities in hydrodynamics caused by the position of the solid with the catalyst (e.g., channeling), uncertainty in the temperature of the catalyst due to differences in the position of thermocouples and other factors. These forms of uncertainty cannot be captured by simple propagation of error from individual measurements (e.g., flow rate and thermocouple calibrations performed in absence of a catalyst). 5 Conclusions Rigorous and reproducible measurements of the kinetics of catalytic reactions and the testing and evaluation of catalytic materials within reactive environments remain the keystone of catalysis science. This statement applies to investigations that seek to demonstrate the performance of catalytic materials, to establish structure function relationships, or to determine the mechanism of catalytic reactions and endure for archival literature or reports in any format (i.e., journal articles, internal reports, patent applications, etc.). Catalysis practitioners must design their investigations to include appropriate experiments and calculations that allow others to reproduce their findings, to quantify key parameters, and to characterize the reported values as intrinsic measurements of chemical kinetics or system-dependent catalyst performance. In brief, practitioners should aim to eliminate consequential concentration and temperature gradients with respect to space and time within the reactors. When these gradients are inherent to the reaction network, the gradients should be characterized and reported in a manner that allows others to reconstruct the testing system and reproduce the measurements. We include primary references to foundational reports that provide guidance and procedures, and within this article, we provide a representative workflow (Scheme 2) that researchers may use when planning investigations that involve catalyst testing. Investigations should begin with the selection and construction of an appropriate reactor with facilities for measurement and control of fluid flow, fluid composition, and catalyst temperature and pressure that must be well documented. Prior to performing experiments that address the central hypotheses or questions of the study, practitioners should conduct control experiments that characterize the impact of reactor (Fig. 4) and pellet scale (Fig. 6) transport phenomena on the measurements acquired. Subsequently, researchers should report intensive measurements (e.g., normalized rates, rates as functions of concentrations, temperature, flowrates) whenever possible, because these quantities allow for the most robust comparisons between materials, reactors, and research laboratories. Several common pitfalls include reports of data from incompletely characterized reactors, systems with unclear time-dependent performance (e.g., not at steady state), or that operate at or near the limits of conversion for key reactants. These recommendations and best practices will lead to high-fidelity catalyst testing and maintain the rigor of our science. CRediT authorship contribution statement David W. coredata.dc:description: Experimental testing and evaluation of catalysts in reactors is a central feature of fundamental catalysis science and reaction engineering. Measurements must be reproducible and interpretable to provide evidence for mechanistic studies or structure–function relationships, or to yield robust and intrinsically meaningful parameters to enable reactor scale-up and process development. Consequently, catalysis practitioners should seek to plan and perform catalyst testing in a manner that distinguishes between the intrinsic chemical kinetics governed by the catalyst and hydrodynamic, transport, and deactivation processes introduced by the form of the catalyst, the reactor vessel, and the nature of the contacting fluid. We highlight the importance of clear testing procedures for both the individual practitioner and the catalysis community and then discuss the sources and methods to address key sources of artifacts in catalyst testing. We organize sections in the form of questions practitioners should ask themselves when planning a catalyst testing campaign. This article references the original literature but also recasts the catalyst testing procedure in the form of a workflow diagram and illustrated depictions of the control experiments implemented within our laboratories to minimize the occurrence of artifacts. The content reflects our collective knowledge in the design, set up, and use of laboratory scale reactors for catalyst testing.
coredata.dc:title: Improving the rigor and reproducibility of catalyst testing and evaluation in the laboratory
